sen.e: Senzai Wakashu is one of the Chokusen Wakashu (anthology of Japanese poetry compiled by Imperial command).

sen.j: 『詞花和歌集』の後、『新古今和歌集』の前に位置し、八代集の第七である。
sen.e: It is the seventh anthology of Hachidaishu (the eight Imperial anthologies of Japanese poetry), and was completed before "Shinkokin Wakashu" (New Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry) and after "Shika Wakashu" (Shika collection of Japanese poems).
sen.cmt: 八代集→勅撰和歌集の初めの八集です。

sen.j: 寿永二年（1183年） 後白河天皇の下命により、藤原俊成が着手し、文治四年（1188年）4月22日に奏覧。
sen.e: In 1183, Emperor Goshirakawa ordered FUJIWARA no Toshinari to compile the anthology, and on April 22, 1188, he submitted it to the Emperor for inspection.

sen.j: 俊成の私撰集『三五代集』を基に編纂されたという。
sen.e: It is said that the anthology was compiled on the basis of Toshinari's personal collection of poetry, "Sangodaishu" (Collection of Fifteen Eras).

sen.j: 構成は春（上・下）、夏、秋（上・下）、冬、離別、羇旅、哀傷、賀、恋（五巻）、雑（上・中・下）、釈教、神祇の部立からなる二十巻で、歌数は1288首。
sen.e: It consists of twenty volumes, including 1288 poems which were categorized into Spring (two volumes), Summer, Autumn (two volumes), Winter, Separation, Journey, Elegies, Celebration, Love (five volumes), Miscellaneous (three volumes), Shakyamuni's teachings, and Gods of heaven and earth.

It consists of 20 volumes, including 1288 poems categorized into Spring (two volumes), Summer, Autumn (two volumes), Winter, Separation, Journey, Elegies, Celebration, Love (five volumes), Miscellaneous (three volumes), Shakyamuni's teachings, and Gods of Heaven and Earth.

sen.j: そのほとんどが短歌である。
sen.e: Most of the poems are tanka (thirty-one syllables' poem).
Most of the poems are tanka (31-syllable poems).

sen.j: 一条天皇朝の正暦年間（実は永延の始め）を上限に、代々の勅撰集に漏れた秀歌や、当代の歌人の作品を収める。
sen.e: The oldest poems collected in the anthology were made during the Shoryaku era (in fact, the beginning of the Eien era), the reign of the Emperor Ichijo, and excellent poems which had not been selected for the successive Chokusenshu (anthologies of poems collected by Imperial command) and poems composed by the contemporary poets were collected into this anthology.

The oldest poems collected in the anthology were made during the Shoryaku era (in fact, the beginning of the Eien era), the reign of the Emperor Ichijo, and excellent poems that had not been selected for the successive Chokusenshu (anthologies of poems collected by imperial command) and poems composed by the contemporary poets were gathered in this anthology.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: It contains excellent poems that had not been selected for the successive Chokusenshu (anthologies of poems collected by imperial command) and poems composed by the contemporary poets; the oldest poems were made during 990 to 995 (in fact, the beginning of the period from 987 and 989), the reign of the Emperor Ichijo.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。グレゴリオ暦にしました。

sen.j: 選歌の方針は格調と抒情性を重んじ、俊成が唱えた「幽玄」の心や、本歌取りなどの技巧を特色とする。
sen.e: Toshinari selected poems considering a refined style and delineation of feelings important, so the anthology is characterized by 'subtle and profound' beauty and poetic devices such as honkadori (adaptation of a famous poem).

Toshinari selected poems considering a refined style and delineation of important feelings, so the anthology is characterized by 'subtle and profound' beauty and poetic devices such as honkadori (adaptation of a famous poem).

sen.j: 最多入集歌人は『金葉和歌集』撰者の源俊頼（52首）で、俊成自身（36首）がそれに次ぐ。
sen.e: The poems selected mostly were composed by MINAMOTO no Toshiyori (52 poems), who was a selector of "Kinyo Wakashu" (Kinyo Collection of Japanese poems) and the second most were by Toshinari (36 poems).

sen.j: 藤原基俊（26首）・崇徳天皇（23首）ら政治の敗者も上位を占める。
sen.e: The political losers' poems also hold superior positions: FUJIWARA no Mototoshi (26 poems) and Emperor Sutoku (23 poems).

sen.j: 他に当代歌人では俊恵・円位法師（西行）・待賢門院堀河・式子内親王、王朝歌人では和泉式部・紫式部・大江匡房・藤原公任などが目立つ。
sen.e: Other contemporary poets were Shune, Buddhist priest Eni (Saigyo), Taikenmonin Horikawa, and Imperial Princess Shikishi, while the dynastic poets who had composed prominent poems were Izumi Shikibu, Murasaki Shikibu, OE no Masafusa, and FUJIWARA no Kinto.

sen.j: 先の『詞花』に反して当代重視主義に戻り、同時代の入集歌数は全体の半数に及んだ。

sen.e: When TAIRA no Tadanori was driven out of the capital, he dropped in at the residence of FUJIWARA no Toshinari and left a scroll of his poems with him, so Toshinari selected one poem as anonymous from them.
